page.title: 20The future of Heybridge
page.content: Although an ancient place, Heybridge owes much of its present position to the canal. That stretch of water brought with it work and money. Not least was the importance of Bentall's which made farming machinery and moved to Heybridge in 1811 to take advantage of the canal. The factory and the warehouse were important symbols of Heybridge. However, Bentall's has now gone and the jobs with them. Yet other firms are springing up and taking its place and there is talk of converting the old factory into a new shopping precinct which would bring new work to the area. Heybridge has been a port, a farming centre, a canal and industrial complex and in the future..? Heybridge is nothing if it is not adaptable.{ {*This document was compiled by the {classses of Julia Brown, Keith {Bannister and Howard Lee in 1985.*
